#Text= fats that cook out from the roast beef, pot roast, soups and corned
#Text= beef.
#Text=This fat is clarified and then used for sautéing.
#Text=It cannot be
#Text= used with good results for making pastry and cakes.
#Text=To clarify fat: Put the fat in a saucepan and add one cupful of cold
#Text= water to every pound of fat.
#Text=Add
#Text=
#Text= One-fourth teaspoon of bicarbonate of soda,
#Text= One-half teaspoon of salt
#Text=
#Text= Bring to a boil and then simmer slowly for ten minutes.
#Text=Pour through
#Text= a strainer lined with cheesecloth and allow to harden, then cut into
#Text=pieces.
#Text=Reheat and pour into jars.
#Text=Bacon, sausage and ham fats may be
#Text= blended with beef drippings for frying purposes.
#Text=Mutton or lamb fat must be clarified and then blended with ham and
#Text= bacon or sausage fat.
#Text=Fat from bacon, ham and sausages may be used for
#Text= flavoring vegetables in place of butter, for cooking omelets, potato
#Text= cakes, mush and scrapple.
#Text=It is a splendid seasoning to use for
#Text= macaroni, baked beans with tomato sauce, dried beans and peas in soups
#Text= and when cooking dried lima beans.
#Text=There is really no need to allow a
#Text= spoonful of these fats to be wasted.
#Text=Fats that are not available for
#Text= table use should be collected and made into soap.
#Text=Do not be falsely economical in trying to do deep frying with these
#Text= fats.
#Text=They not only will not hold the temperature for successful
#Text= frying without scorching, but they frequently soak into the food and
#Text= make it unfit to eat.
#Text=The late war has brought many good vegetable oils upon the market that
#Text= are ideal for cooking purposes and are preferable to the animal
#Text= fats for all cooking.
#Text=They not only hold a high temperature without
#Text=fruits, but fresh fruit as well.
#Text=When cooked tender, drain the liquid from the fruit and measure.
#Text=Allow
#Text= one-half cup of sugar to every three cups of juice.
#Text=Place this juice
#Text= and the sugar in a separate saucepan and boil until thick; then pour
#Text= over the fruit.
#Text=Dried fruits prepared this way will be found to be delicious.
#Text=Apricots
#Text= will require very little cooking, so drain them free from the liquid
#Text= in which they are soaked and add the sugar.
#Text=Boil the syrup until thick
#Text= and then pour over the apricots and cook gently for ten minutes.
#Text=Remove the skins from peaches, after soaking them, and before cooking
#Text= add a little piece of thin orange peel for flavor.
#Text=To prepare dried pears soak them for twelve hours and then place in a
#Text= casserole dish and add to one-half pound of fruit
#Text=
#Text= One cup of brown sugar.
#Text=Juice of one lemon,
#Text=accurate measurements for seasoning and flavoring.
#Text=A spatula will repay its cost many times over the first month it is
#Text= used.
#Text=It is possible with this knife to remove every particle of food
#Text= from a mixing bowl.
#Text=How can you keep a house without a pair of reliable scales?
#Text=Do you
#Text= know how much the chicken weighed that you bought on Saturday, and do
#Text= you know how much waste there was; or the weight of the bone in
#Text= the meat that you purchased on Wednesday?
#Text=Do you ever weigh your
#Text= purchases?
#Text=Think this over and then buy a good pair of scales and keep
#Text= them in a convenient place.
#Text=List of equivalent measures:--
#Text= 1  salt spoon   1/4 teaspoon
#Text= 3  teaspoons    1 tablespoon
#Text= 3  tablespoons  1 cooking spoon
#Text= 4  tablespoons  1/4 cup
#Text= 8  tablespoons  1/2 cup
#Text= 12 tablespoons  3/4 cup
#Text=For this reason it is one of the most popular cuts.
#Text=Seventh, porterhouse.
#Text=This portion of the loin contains the choicest
#Text= steaks, excellent and nutritious and easily cooked.
#Text=The fillet or
#Text= tenderloin forms a part of the loin and averages about 13 per cent.
#Text=waste.
#Text=Eighth, rump.
#Text=This cut is very nutritious, but requires careful
#Text= cooking to render it tender; it contains slightly more waste than the
#Text= round.
#Text=Good steaks are obtained from the rump; it is also used for pot
#Text= roast braising and coming.
#Text=Ninth, pin bone, the middle portion of the loin.
#Text=It is of excellent
#Text= quality, tender and of good flavor and quite as popular as the loin.
#Text=It is the face cut of the rump.
#Text=Tenth, round.
#Text=An inexpensive cut, containing only 7 per cent, waste.
#Text=It is nutritious as tenderloin, but not as tender.
#Text=The first essential
#Text= in cooking is to sear the outside in order to retain the juices and
#Text= then cook slowly until tender.
#Text=then it should be cooked just below the boiling point until tender,
#Text= allowing one-half hour for the meat to heat and start cooking and then
#Text= twenty-five minutes to the pound.
#Text=Add salt just before removing from
#Text= the fire.
#Text=Keep this fact in mind, that salt will, if added when the meat is just
#Text= starting to cook, extract the juice.
#Text=For pot roast and braises, etc., it is necessary to quickly sear over
#Text= the surface of the meat for the same reason that the meat was plunged
#Text= into boiling water and then cook slowly, allowing the same proportion
#Text= of time as for boiling or stewing.
#Text=The real object in cooking meat is to retain the juices and make it
#Text= sufficiently to eat and increase its flavor.
#Text=BEEF STEW
#Text=
#Text= Cut two and one-half pounds of stewing beef in two-inch pieces and
#Text=cornstarch pudding, 188
#Text= filling for cakes made from cocoa, 71

#Text= [Illustration: "_I never grate chocolate anymore!
#Text=
#Text= I give my icings, fillings, pies and puddings "_that chocolaty
#Text= taste_" of Runkel  '  s without bothering to grate chocolate.
#Text=It not only
#Text= improves the flavor, but saves 1/4 the cost.
#Text=Interesting Dessert Book, "_The New Cocoa Cookery_", will be
#Text= sent you gratis upon request.
